newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico loses NAFTA cement-dumping dispute with US.
newsitem.headline: Mexico loses NAFTA cement-dumping dispute with US.

text.p: A trade-dispute resolution panel empowered by the North American Free Trade Agreement has upheld a U.S. anti-dumping duty on Mexican cement, Mexico's Commerce Ministry said on Tuesday.

The ministry said in a statement that the panel -- made up of three U.S. representatives and two Mexicans -- unanimously agreed on Friday that the compensatory tariff complied with U.S. law and was therefore legal.
Mexico will continue to use "all legal means" to overturn the ruling and allow Mexican cement free access to the U.S. market, the statement said.
U.S. cement makers accused Mexico of selling gray portland and clinker cement at below-cost prices and won a ruling from the U.S. Commerce Department.

Exports to the U.S. by Mexico's largest cement maker, Cemex S.A., dropped after the Commerce Department's ruling, but the company now depends very little on the U.S. market for its exports, Cemex officials said.
